posts.description:
Upon meeting Roman shoemaker, Gianluca Bocache for the first time last December, I enquired as who he held as style icons - to which he named the usual suspects of sartorial splendour in Cary Grant and Fred Astaire. Interestingly though, he also mentioned Bing Crosby - a man surely known by sartorial pundits, but perhaps less so than his Hollywood Golden Age counterparts.

An American performer equally renowned for his acting as he was for his voice, Crosby was in fact the best selling recording artist of the 20th century, selling in excess of one billion copies.

Such were the social constructs of the time, that Crosby was typically suit-clad for much of his work - which, thankfully, has been forevermore encapsulated through the lens of various photographers and videographers - the timeless appeal of his style still enduring to this day.
.
.
.

Once a refreshing take on menswear photography - imbuing images with the real-world relevance unattainable in normal campaign shots - street style photography has since become somewhat ubiquitous and a little contrived.

Eschewing this norm though is New York street style veteran, Guerre, who captures his subjects in a more authentic light, typically with little staging. One such example is this image of his long-term friend and collaborator in Jonathan Edwards - cutting a powerful and enigmatic figure as he is captured wearing this black tie ensemble in context (en route to one of the numerous formal evenings held) during Pitti season- an environment which often stipulates a formal dress code, and where he wields an almost Anna Wintour-like influence in the realm of sartorialism. @guerreisms @milanstylelive
.
.
.

Having recently explored the orange ensemble through a seasonal lens - featuring both summer and autumnal outfits - the time is nigh to explore something a little more four-seasonal - albeit, perhaps the most polarising orange outfit to date…

Whilst it’s highly unlikely that anyone with more than a modicum of taste would ever wear this outfit, it is befitting of Robert De Niro’s character, Sam “Ace” Rothstein in the the 1995 crime drama, Casino, where orange is used to denote status - to show that rules are null and void to Ace. An interesting use of colour indeed, and one that perhaps highlights the underlying effects of orange in sartorialism.
.
.
.

As polarising as it may be, the fashion of extending and exposing the rear blade of the tie has been extolled by sartorial enthusiasts the world over - becoming somewhat of a symbol of new-age sartorialism.

Whilst the purveyors of such an aesthetic often prescribe to more timeless style in their tailoring, the tie is exempt from such shackles - as it needn’t be tied this way for eternity should fashion dictate a change.

Worn by Maciej Zaremba - owner of the eponymous Polish tailoring house, Zaremba - the suit, cut from a grey plaid cloth, is worn with a light blue striped shirt - a classically influenced ensemble befitting of Zaremba’s rich history dating back to 1894.

Within the sartorial sphere, where classicism is perhaps somewhat ubiquitous and constrained (not that this is a negative), the extended rear blade denotes a certain freedom of expression and indeed an allegiance to more modern tastes - perhaps as part of a broader mission to detach oneself from the idea of ‘pretension’ that people may often associate with tailoring.
@zarembabespoke
.
.
.

To extrapolate on our recent discussion on orange, behold this burnt orange creation shaped by the shears of Neapolitan stalwarts, Cesare Attolini - arguably more conventional than the previous ensemble courtesy of B & Tailor.

Whilst it hasn’t completely shaken the inherent braggadocio of orange clothing, it is certainly more mellow than the previous ensemble which featured hues of green in a gun club check configuration.

Despite the blue windowpane of the jacket, the blue stripes of the shirt and the blue tie, the outfit still permeates a distinctly autumnal vibe. @cesareattolininapoli
.
.
.

Not having any perfect rhymes within the english language, orange has remained similarly obscure within the realm of sartorialism - for despite its positive psychological underpinnings as a beacon of energy and happiness, it is marred by a lack of versatility. 
Whilst warmer hues of burnt orange are perhaps the most common variation of the colour within sartorialism - often conjuring thoughts of autumn - brighter hues  are almost non-existent.

Eschewing this norm however, in an anti-establishment, middle-finger-to-the-air kind of way, are Korean artisans B & Tailor. Undoubtedly polarising, this ensemble subverts the usual autumnal associations of orange in clothing, and instead permeates a more ‘summery’ feel. @bntailor
.
.
.

Whilst they are perhaps more renowned for their contributions in the realm of design - spanning the disciplines of architecture, interior and industrial - it would seem that Scandinavia’s prowess has disseminated more broadly into fashion - specially Scandinavian sartorialism, where the outfits reflect the regions architecture, in that they invariably appear so well ‘put together’ and considered.

The growing host of nordic influencers seems to have conceived a swagger of new brands - a large number of whom are based in Sweden - all operating under the auspices of Scandinavian taste, with their intelligent and pragmatic designs. Devoid of any unnecessary extravagance, there is an understated opulence to Scandinavian style.

Scandinavian sartorialsim often straddles the more casual elements of the male wardrobe - mixing the two together into a delightful concoction somewhat reminiscent of Japanese sartorialism. 
A wonderful exponent of the regions style is Scandinavian sartorialist Erik Mannby - captured here cloaked in a 3 piece suit cut by Swedish brand E-F-V. @erikmannby @efvclothing
.
.
.

"She was beautiful, but she was beautiful in the way a forest fire is beautiful: something to be admired from a distance”, said Neil Gaiman & Terry Pratchett in ‘Omens’ - a sentiment that often extends to windowpane cloth - frequently appreciated within the confines of the swatch book, but less frequently commissioned into garments.

In a world where suiting is often worn as part of a corporate dress code, ubiquity and mundanity tend to reign supreme in terms of cloth - not to say that such things cannot be beautiful when transposed into garments at the hands of the artisan - because they often are. However, the windowpane is certainly less prevalent.

And whilst the windowpane may often conjure up thoughts of some of its boldest iterations - the navy and white windowpane for example - it can be equally subtle - especially in flannel variations where the textured, matte finish mellows the windowpane pattern as it does here. Further aiding this, is the subtle contrast in colour between the grey and the brown/khaki check. Worn with a similarly matte, knitted khaki tie and blue shirt, this effect is again amplified. @paulluxsartoria
.
.
.

Since its inception, the prince of wales check has gradually transitioned to become somewhat insipid - smaller in scale and lacking the same bravado of forgone eras, it often adorns similarly lacklustre garments. Thankfully though, the resurgence of sartorial classicism has seen the large-scale prince of wales check reinstated to the throne of sportive cloths.

Purveyors of such cloths are also enjoying the renewed custom of vintage-impassioned buyers, with establishments such as Fox Brothers, W. Bill, Harrisons and the like, all surging in popularity given the rich provenance and traditionalist sentiment attached to their brands.

Shaped by the shears of Milanese artisan Yuki Inoue, this jacket has been cut from a vintage W. Bill cloth - the sumptuous scale of the pattern imbuing the jacket, and eventually, its wearer with a real sense of masculine bravado. @yukiinouemilano @bespokemakers
.
.
.

Whether it be due to its distinctly ivy league shirt connotations or Ross Geller’s shirt debacle on Friends, the colour salmon is somewhat confined to sartorial obscurity - not featuring prominently in any form - from shirts, to ties, to pocket squares and especially suits. Lacking in versatility, it’s risk of appearing ghastly is more than likely the prominent deterrent - with this risk often belying its charm.

It is interesting then to see this salmon coloured tie used in contrast to a dark charcoal rope stripe suit. Sensibly, a subtly striped shirt has been used to soften the contrast between suit, shirt and tie. Similarly, the pocket square acts as the nexus between the suit, shirt and tie - featuring colours from all three in some kind of geometric abstraction. @maidookini
.
.
.
